CONE AND SLINGLUFF
REPRESENT HOPKINS
AT CONVENTION
250 Colleges Convene At Princeton
To Organize Universities For
World Court Discussion

Maxwell Cone, '27 and Jesse
Slingluff, '26, were the Johns Hopkin.s representatives at a conference of two hundred and fifty colleges held at Princeton, New Jersey last week. The dual purpose
of the meeting was first, to crystallize student opinion on the subject
of the world court, and, second, to
organize the colleges of the country so that discusSions and recommendations on world problems can
be had each year.
The resolution, to be sent to
President Coolidge,- reads as follows: -This conference, representing the undergraduate majorities
of two hundred and fifty colleges,
favors the immediate adherenceof
the United States to the Permanent Court of International Justice, the Harding-Hughes-Coolidge
reservations, as the least step
which can be taken at this time to
further world peace." This was
adopt6d by a vote of two hundred
and forty-four to four, after a discussion lasting several days.
